abyssinian: ticked tabby pattern (each hair has multiple bands of color)
large, almond-shaped eyes (gold, green, or hazel)
american bulldog: coat colors typically white, brindle, or a combination of white with patches of other colors
ears that can be either cropped or natural (typically rose or half-pricked)
a relatively short tail, often thick at the base and tapering to a point
american pit bull terrier: ears that may be cropped or natural (typically semi-prick or rose-shaped)
coat colors can vary widely (e.g., black, white, brindle, blue, red, fawn)
basset hound: tricolor (black, white, and brown) or bicolor (brown and white) coat
beagle: tricolor pattern (typically black, white, and brown/tan)
bengal: distinctive coat patterns (rosettes, spots, or marbling)
coat colors typically include brown, silver, snow, or charcoal
large, almond-shaped eyes (often green or gold)
long, thick tail with a rounded tip
birman: color-pointed coat (darker color on ears, face, paws, and tail)
white "gloves" on front paws and "laces" on back paws
bombay: large, round, and wide-set eyes (usually copper or gold)
boxer: sweat or signs of physical exertion
protective headgear (optional, depending on the context)
stance with fists up and ready to punch
british shorthair: large, round eyes (often copper or gold in color)
thick, medium-length tail with a rounded tip
common coat colors include blue (grey), black, white, red, cream, and various tabby patterns
chihuahua: coat colors such as fawn, black, white, chocolate, cream, or a combination
egyptian mau: coat colors: silver, bronze, smoke, black, or blue/pewter
hind legs longer than front legs
banded tail with a dark tip
english cocker spaniel: coat colors: black, liver, red, golden, or parti-color
feathering on legs, chest, and belly
english setter: coat color typically white with speckles or patches of black, blue, orange, or liver (known as "belton" markings)
feathering on the tail, legs, and underbelly
a long, straight or slightly curved tail
german shorthaired: coat color typically liver (brown), liver and white, or liver roan
distinctive ticking or speckled pattern on the coat
almond-shaped eyes, usually brown or hazel
great pyrenees: thick, double coat of fur, usually white or with light tan, gray, or badger markings
fluffy tail, often carried low or curled over the back
broad head with a slightly rounded skull
havanese: coat colors can include white, black, brown, gray, or a combination
sturdy, slightly longer than tall body
japanese chin: black and white or red and white coloration
a tail that curls over the back
keeshond: fur color typically a mix of grey, black, and cream
bushy tail that curls over the back
mane-like fur around the neck and shoulders
leonberger: coat colors: lion-yellow, golden to reddish-brown, with a black mask
broad head with a slightly domed skull
medium-sized, triangular ears that hang close to the head
maine coon: long, shaggy fur, especially around the neck (ruff)
variety of coat colors and patterns
miniature pinscher: coat colors typically black and tan, chocolate and tan, or red
newfoundland: coat colors typically black, brown, grey, or Landseer (white with black markings)
broad head with a slightly arched crown
small, triangular ears that lie close to the head
bushy tail that may hang down or be carried level with the back
persian: variety of coat colors (white, black, blue, cream, red, etc.)
pomeranian: plumed tail that curls over the back
variety of colors (e.g., orange, black, white, cream, blue, brown)
ragdoll: colorpoint pattern (darker coloration on ears, face, paws, and tail)
distinctive "V" shape on the forehead (in some color patterns)
russian blue: short, dense, and plush blue-grey coat
saint bernard: thick, dense coat (can be short or long-haired)
coat colors typically include white with red, brown, or brindle patches
broad head with a pronounced stop
samoyed: a characteristic "Samoyed smile" with upturned corners of the mouth
bushy tail that curls over the back
scottish terrier: a tail that is often carried upright
shiba inu: coat colors: red, sesame (red with black-tipped hairs), black and tan, or cream
white markings on the chest, legs, and tip of the tail (known as "urajiro")
siamese: light-colored body with darker points (ears, face, paws, and tail)
sphynx: hairless or very short, fine hair
paw pads that appear thicker than those of other cats
staffordshire bull terrier: broad head with a short muzzle
coat colors: black, blue, fawn, red, white, or any of these with white
a relatively short tail that tapers to a point
wheaten terrier: coat color ranges from pale beige to golden tan
tail often carried upright or slightly curved
yorkshire terrier: a high-set tail, often carried slightly higher than the back
